Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The IGERT resource center will provide a web-based infrastructure that will enable projects to share and learn from each other's experience and resources. It will build the capacity of the IGERT program by facilitating a learning organization where lessons learned, curricular enhancements, and emerging research are archived and made available to newly funded projects. The resource center will also enrich the ability of projects to collaborate by providing a suite of interactive online tools and online events. The resource center will further IGERT's goal of expanding and diversifying the STEM talent pool by enhancing individual project's recruitment and dissemination efforts. Further, the resource center will provide trainees with an expanded collegial network to other faculty, mentors, affiliated IGERT partner institutions and current and alumni IGERT trainees. Finally it will provide a centralized, searchable, content rich, online resource for IGERT industry partners, stakeholders, policy makers and the public at large to learn from innovative graduate education programs that bridge disciplinary and institutional boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
IGERT.org served both as a resource center and collegial network for NSF’s IGERT (Integrative Graduate Education Research Traineeship) Program. It was launched in May of 2009 and was actively facilitated until October 1st 2015. The site continues to be available as an archive of IGERT projects’ work and can be accessed at http://igert.org .  Three hundred and five IGERT projects are represented on the site.

This collegial network had over 5,450 active members. 3,139 identified as graduate students, 213 as PIs and 826 as co-PIs, 431 as other faculty members, 170 program coordinators and 504 alumni. From the date of site launch this resource center had over 1.85 million page views, 575,000 sessions from over 400,000 unique users. While 79.6% of visitors came from the US, there was strong international interest with over 20% of sessions originating from over 200 countries.  Countries with the most sessions were India with over 18,000 sessions, the United Kingdom, with over 6,600 sessions, Canada with over 6,000 sessions, and China, Germany, and Puerto Rico, each having over 5,000 sessions. 

IGERT.org was successful in building the capacity of the IGERT program by enabling projects to share their work and learn from each other’s experiences. Members shared with each other by posting to News, Library, Showcase, Job Board, and Conference Board. They also interacted with one another via Site Messages, Interactive Groups, and Webinars. It fostered the work of each project by enhancing their recruitment and dissemination efforts, and by enabling them to use a suite of interactive tools with their own constituents. Trainee and faculty benefitted by having an expanded collegial network.  Prospective students were provided with a clear overview of the program at large and a searchable database of IGERT projects by theme, region, state, and institution. Last it enabled the public at large to learn from the research and resources developed by NSF funded IGERT projects.

In addition to creating and facilitating the IGERT.org resource center this project developed an innovative online platform for the sharing of scientific posters and videos, and facilitated three IGERT competitions. The first of these in 2011 was a poster competition. In 2012 and 2013 the competitions evolved to include both  the sharing of posters as well as science videos.

The 2013 competition which can be viewed at http://igert2013.videohall.com  had participation from 119 IGERT projects, each of whom produced a video and poster. During the five days of the competition, scientific dialogue was exchanged. Over 1,300 messages were posted by faculty judges and presenters and an additional 1,124 messages were exchanged by the community at large. To date the videos of this competition have been viewed 43,980 times and the posters have ben viewed 13, 524 times.

The event was also extraordinary in its reach to the public. During the week of the 2013 competition there were 52,110 sessions from over 40,000 unique visitors from 150 countries. Remarkably the competition, now long over, continues to attract people to the site. Since the competition has ended, there has been an additional 26,000 sessions from over 20,000 additional unique visitors. 

While there are many venues to share videos online, the competitions were extraordinarily successful in facilitating rich collegial discourse. Students reported getting valuable feedback on their work, learning how to use video to explain their work to a public audience, making new connections to others in their field, (some even getting job offers,) and for the first time being able to share their scientific work in a meaningful way with their community and family.
